questions.question: What is the fundamental process that creates the continuous part of the X-ray spectrum?
options: Electrons being absorbed by the nucleus.
High-speed electrons slowing down as they pass near a nucleus.
Electrons jumping from the L-shell to the K-shell.
Protons being ejected from the target.
questions.explanation: Bremsstrahlung ('braking radiation'): electrons decelerate in nuclear Coulomb field, emitting photons with continuous energy range (up to electron's kinetic energy). Produces smooth background in X-ray spectrum.

questions.question: In an X-ray tube, if the accelerating potential is $V$, what is the maximum energy a single X-ray photon can have?
questions.explanation: Electron gains kinetic energy $KE = eV$ from potential difference. Maximum photon energy = electron's entire KE (in single collision): $E_{max} = hf_{max} = eV$. Duane-Hunt law: $\lambda_{min} = hc/(eV)$.

questions.question: The 'minimum wavelength' ($\lambda_{min}$) in an X-ray spectrum corresponds to:
options: The electron that lost the least amount of energy.
An electron that gave up its entire kinetic energy in a single collision.
questions.explanation: $\lambda_{min}$ = shortest wavelength = highest frequency = maximum photon energy. Occurs when electron loses all KE to single photon. Shorter wavelengths impossible - violates energy conservation.

questions.question: Which of the following will decrease the minimum wavelength ($\lambda_{min}$) of the produced X-rays?
questions.explanation: $\lambda_{min} \propto 1/V$. Higher voltage → faster electrons → higher possible photon energy → shorter $\lambda_{min}$. Filament current affects intensity (photon count), not maximum energy.

questions.question: On a graph of X-ray intensity vs. wavelength, the sharp 'spikes' or peaks are called:
questions.explanation: Characteristic lines: discrete wavelengths specific to target material. From inner-shell electron transitions. Bremsstrahlung = continuous background. Gamma rays come from nucleus, not electron transitions.

questions.question: If you want to increase the number of X-rays produced without changing their energy, you should:
options: Decrease the distance to the target.
questions.explanation: Filament current controls electron emission rate → controls tube current → controls X-ray intensity (photons/sec). Voltage controls photon energies. Distance affects intensity at detector but not production rate.

questions.question: X-rays are part of the electromagnetic spectrum. This means they travel at what speed in a vacuum?
questions.explanation: All electromagnetic waves travel at $c = 3.00\times 10^8\ \text{m/s}$ in vacuum. Speed depends only on medium, not frequency. Sound = 340 m/s, $g$ = acceleration.

questions.question: Why is the efficiency of an X-ray tube very low (usually $< 1\%$)?
options: Most of the electron's kinetic energy is converted into heat in the target.
X-rays are absorbed by the glass tube.
The filament takes too much power.
questions.explanation: Electrons undergo many collisions, losing energy gradually as heat (~99%). Only ~1% of electron KE converts to X-rays via bremsstrahlung. Targets need active cooling (water/oil).

questions.question: The Duane-Hunt limit ($hc/\lambda_{min} = eV$) is a proof of:
questions.explanation: Shows photon energy $E = hf$ is quantized, not continuous. Electron's kinetic energy $eV$ converts to photon energy $hf_{max}$ in discrete packets. Classical wave theory couldn't explain sharp cutoff.

questions.question: Characteristic X-rays are produced when:
options: An incident electron knocks an inner-shell electron out of a target atom.
The magnetic field is turned off.
questions.explanation: Incident electron creates vacancy in inner shell (e.g., K-shell). Outer-shell electron drops into vacancy, emitting X-ray photon with energy = shell difference. Produces discrete spectral lines unique to element.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered the essential concepts of X-ray production including bremsstrahlung mechanism, Duane-Hunt law, characteristic radiation origins, and tube operational parameters.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Solid understanding of X-ray basics. Review: 1) Continuous vs. characteristic spectrum distinction, 2) Voltage vs. filament current effects, 3) Energy conservation in photon production, 4) Efficiency and practical considerations.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Focus on: 1) How X-rays are produced (electron deceleration), 2) Minimum wavelength relationship with voltage, 3) Characteristic lines from atomic transitions, 4) Difference between intensity and energy control, 5) Why tubes are inefficient.
scoreMessages.0: Start with fundamentals: Review what X-rays are (high-frequency EM waves), how X-ray tubes work, and the two processes (bremsstrahlung and characteristic) that create X-rays.
